Jack W, 1993 - 

May contain spoilers.

Images within reviews sourced from IMDb (unless indicated otherwise)

title: REVIEW: Captain Marvel
body:
Film: Captain Marvel (2019)
Director: Anna Boden, Ryan Fleck
Starring: Brie Larson, Samuel L Jackson, Ben Mendelsohn, Djimon Hounsou, Lee Pace, Lashana Lynch, Gemma Chan, Annette Bening, Clark Gregg, Jude Law

For nigh on 11 years, Marvel Studios and it’s Cinematic Universe has been relentlessly invading our cinemas with bombastic blockbusters. Spoiling us with post-credit teaser scenes, interconnected storylines and a plethora of heroes popping up all over. It is difficult therefore to compute why it has taken so long, with all that source material, for a film to emerge with a female solo lead. Like it or not, both the current climate in the industry and the historic prevalence of testosterone in this franchise could only mean that Captain Marvel was expected to make a strong, feminist statement - would this be at the expense of the story being told?​

The trouble with films in a successful franchise is high expectations - both from established fans of the source material and from the precedent set by previous successes. This can be a double-edged sword, as we have seen with The Last Jedi, causing upset amongst an angsty fanbase - get this wrong at your peril. For Captain Marvel, this expectation was catalysed by gender - arguably entirely placing the fault with Marvel for being the sole cause of the long delay.

The audience is immediately flung out into space, specifically, Hala - home of a race of aliens called the Kree. We meet amnesiac Vers (later, Carol Danvers) who is a plucky-yet-rebellious human/Kree with superpowers. She is a member of a warrior/hero, alien brigade called Starforce. These heroes are fighting a battle against the Kree’s malevolent shape-shifting enemies, the Skrulls. Naturally, the fight is brought to an unsuspecting Earth, and an equally unsuspecting Carol discovers that in the grey spaces of her memory, she once had a life on Earth.​

Carol must then protect Earth and other innocents from being caught in the crossfire of this ongoing war, whilst learning to harness and tame her powerful abilities and discovering the secrets hidden in her past. In many ways, this has all the fundamental ingredients of a classic MCU origin tale. So where are all these essential feminist elements that we were promised?

Mostly, there aren’t any. Giving this film special treatment in my mind would do away with much of what it tries to achieve. Carol is a new member of the wider MCU family - her story is her own and adapting this into a purely girls-only, feminism-centric fable would alienate more than would be helpful. It would set a dangerous precedent that all future female-fronted movies in the franchise should be different from the others. This of course is a fiction. Moreover, this would not be equality. Captain Marvel’s MO shouldn’t be to take the mantle for womankind - she only had this expectation thrust upon her by being the first female-solo-lead in the franchise. Instead, the film rightly establishes her as a totally bad-ass, ultra-powerful hero; an asset to the Avengers team and the wider MCU family, irrespective of her gender.​

The closest the film comes to making such a statement is when Carol finally realises her true potential. She throws off the chains limiting her power (a glass ceiling, if you will) and learns to harness her incredible abilities with aplomb. Not only can she then thwart her enemies, but she cleans up without so much as breaking a sweat. Clearly a metaphor that I’m sure feminists can get on board with - the strength of women is not to be suppressed but embraced. Indeed suppress the strength of a powerful woman at your own risk!

As a piece of entertainment, this film undeniably succeeds. Time and again, Marvel has shown its greatest weapon is its comedic timing. Captain Marvel is no different. The chemistry and banter between the main characters is rewarding - and keep an eye out for Goose the cat. The action sequences are also a treat - there’s a car/train chase that it very reminiscent of The French Connection - and I’m not over-doing it by say I was truly blown away by the effects, and clearly how powerful a hero Carol is. She could kick the entire roster of the MCU into touch - easily. All I can say here is, roll on April and the arrival of Avengers: Endgame.

Your reception of Captain Marvel will, as with any other film, depend on your expectations. If you expect a female empowerment movie, you may well be disappointed. If you expect to be entertained, to indulge your inner child, and if you want super cool action sequences with some laughs along the way, you won’t be. Carol will no doubt be a role model for a generation of young girls, but the biggest disappointment is only that she didn’t arrived sooner.​

Jack’s Score: 8/10

body:
Cat cat flerken

Some time after Fury adopts Goose he also adopted a perfectly normal cat that looks identical. He names it Duck.

Human children growing up on Earth play Duck Duck Goose.

Alien children growing up on Earth play Cat Cat Flerken.

summary: Just got home from seeing Captain Marvel...
body:
Just got home from seeing Captain Marvel…

… and asked my cat to meow once if she’s an alien. Well she meowed and now I’m really afraid to tell her no more treats because she bit me last week and I have a feeling it was an alien warning not to fuck with her.

summary: Cptn Marvel was a paint-by-number effort on Disney’s part (and pretty sure girls aren’t going to be threatened by the airforce’s...
body:
Cptn Marvel was a paint-by-number effort on Disney’s part (and pretty sure girls aren’t going to be threatened by the airforce’s recruiting ad in it, they very rarely face that kind of thing in the first place and secondly, wouldn’t do the military any harm to have a few more women running things) but I did appreciate how they didn’t feel the need to shoehorn her into any kind of romantic relationship. Instead they showed her as having close, emotionally supportive relationships with multiple people, both male and female. She and her boss, she and her Cree captain (aside from late-movie spoilers, “control your emotions because you have emotionally-triggered world-ending superpowers” is not a bad thing.) Also liked how she was comfortable enough to go straight to him when she had a problem and wasn’t afraid to be honest about it. Her and her foster-sister on earth (foster, if I’m interpreting the line about her being taken away from her own family and placed with them, otherwise just family-of-choice) etc. and then her hilarious dynamic with Fury. Way to go showing a natural range of human relationships across gender and generation without applying a romantic overlay. Young kids need to understand that close friendships don’t equate to sexual attraction or end in sexual encounters. 

Still paint-by-number though. When the most groundbreaking thing in the film is the female lead not kissing anyone, congrats Disney you have established a baseline, not a mountaintop. 


And please please can someone somewhere someday put a female superhero on the big screen and have her solve problems by not destroying things. I know the special effects are awesome when stuff goes boom but seriously. Punching people to win is not male/female hero equality, it’s an uncreative return to the lowest common denominator.

reblog.comment:
Cptn Marvel was a paint-by-number effort on Disney’s part (and pretty sure girls aren’t going to be threatened by the airforce’s recruiting ad in it, they very rarely face that kind of thing in the first place and secondly, wouldn’t do the military any harm to have a few more women running things) but I did appreciate how they didn’t feel the need to shoehorn her into any kind of romantic relationship. Instead they showed her as having close, emotionally supportive relationships with multiple people, both male and female. She and her boss, she and her Cree captain (aside from late-movie spoilers, “control your emotions because you have emotionally-triggered world-ending superpowers” is not a bad thing.) Also liked how she was comfortable enough to go straight to him when she had a problem and wasn’t afraid to be honest about it. Her and her foster-sister on earth (foster, if I’m interpreting the line about her being taken away from her own family and placed with them, otherwise just family-of-choice) etc. and then her hilarious dynamic with Fury. Way to go showing a natural range of human relationships across gender and generation without applying a romantic overlay. Young kids need to understand that close friendships don’t equate to sexual attraction or end in sexual encounters. 

Still paint-by-number though. When the most groundbreaking thing in the film is the female lead not kissing anyone, congrats Disney you have established a baseline, not a mountaintop. 


And please please can someone somewhere someday put a female superhero on the big screen and have her solve problems by not destroying things. I know the special effects are awesome when stuff goes boom but seriously. Punching people to win is not male/female hero equality, it’s an uncreative return to the lowest common denominator.

trail.content_raw:
Cptn Marvel was a paint-by-number effort on Disney’s part (and pretty sure girls aren’t going to be threatened by the airforce’s recruiting ad in it, they very rarely face that kind of thing in the first place and secondly, wouldn’t do the military any harm to have a few more women running things) but I did appreciate how they didn’t feel the need to shoehorn her into any kind of romantic relationship. Instead they showed her as having close, emotionally supportive relationships with multiple people, both male and female. She and her boss, she and her Cree captain (aside from late-movie spoilers, “control your emotions because you have emotionally-triggered world-ending superpowers” is not a bad thing.) Also liked how she was comfortable enough to go straight to him when she had a problem and wasn’t afraid to be honest about it. Her and her foster-sister on earth (foster, if I’m interpreting the line about her being taken away from her own family and placed with them, otherwise just family-of-choice) etc. and then her hilarious dynamic with Fury. Way to go showing a natural range of human relationships across gender and generation without applying a romantic overlay. Young kids need to understand that close friendships don’t equate to sexual attraction or end in sexual encounters. 

Still paint-by-number though. When the most groundbreaking thing in the film is the female lead not kissing anyone, congrats Disney you have established a baseline, not a mountaintop. 


And please please can someone somewhere someday put a female superhero on the big screen and have her solve problems by not destroying things. I know the special effects are awesome when stuff goes boom but seriously. Punching people to win is not male/female hero equality, it’s an uncreative return to the lowest common denominator.
trail.content:
Cptn Marvel was a paint-by-number effort on Disney’s part (and pretty sure girls aren’t going to be threatened by the airforce’s recruiting ad in it, they very rarely face that kind of thing in the first place and secondly, wouldn’t do the military any harm to have a few more women running things) but I did appreciate how they didn’t feel the need to shoehorn her into any kind of romantic relationship. Instead they showed her as having close, emotionally supportive relationships with multiple people, both male and female. She and her boss, she and her Cree captain (aside from late-movie spoilers, “control your emotions because you have emotionally-triggered world-ending superpowers” is not a bad thing.) Also liked how she was comfortable enough to go straight to him when she had a problem and wasn’t afraid to be honest about it. Her and her foster-sister on earth (foster, if I’m interpreting the line about her being taken away from her own family and placed with them, otherwise just family-of-choice) etc. and then her hilarious dynamic with Fury. Way to go showing a natural range of human relationships across gender and generation without applying a romantic overlay. Young kids need to understand that close friendships don’t equate to sexual attraction or end in sexual encounters. 

Still paint-by-number though. When the most groundbreaking thing in the film is the female lead not kissing anyone, congrats Disney you have established a baseline, not a mountaintop. 


And please please can someone somewhere someday put a female superhero on the big screen and have her solve problems by not destroying things. I know the special effects are awesome when stuff goes boom but seriously. Punching people to win is not male/female hero equality, it’s an uncreative return to the lowest common denominator.

blog.name: gamorazenwhoberis
blog.title: showtime, a-holes!
blog.description: caitlin. 30. my life is a neverending marvel cosmic meltdown. ao3.

tags: i know i already wrote a post about this lol but this is my soapbox and i'm not leaving
summary: after having seen captain marvel now that I look at the trailer for endgame I just see her and go "what did they do to you" ...
question: after having seen captain marvel now that I look at the trailer for endgame I just see her and go "what did they do to you"  because like, even her hair is longer.  they really went all out trying to sex her up and she doesn't look like herself at all anymore... like... the fuck.
answer:
i had the same thought right when i saw the trailer. the contrast between captain marvel, which had women as part of its creative team, versus avengers: endgame, which has a principal creative team composed entirely of white men, is stark; we suddenly have a sexualized female hero, which wasn’t the case when women were involved in making the decisions regarding how she presents onscreen.

this fandom is blowing up with a bunch of wank now about whether or not it’s “okay” or “feminist” to wear makeup, but that’s really not the point. carol danvers is a fictional character who isn’t choosing any of these things for herself, and the source of the differences in her appearance is, in my opinion, pretty clear.

summary: So, hear me out. We have seen, because of the toys and the trailer itself, that the avengers are wearing quantum suits to travel...
body:
Avengers 4 Theory

So, hear me out. We have seen, because of the toys and the trailer itself, that the avengers are wearing quantum suits to travel through the Quantum Real.

Now, the ONLY ONES who aren’t wearing them are Carol and Valkyrie (we can see it by the differents leaked toys). Even Hulk has the suit, although we haven’t saw it before, but here it is:

And Carol and Valkyrie without the suit:

So, it’s known that Carol is the most powerful character in the MCU, she maybe can travel easily through the Quantum Real; Valkyrie is an asgardian and for that, she is very strong and powerful but not as much as Thor and he is wearing the quantum suit. Here’s the question:

Why Valkyrie hasn’t the quantum suit??

Is she going to stay in the Earth?, and if that’s the case, why is she staying? Maybe with the other asgardians that survived the snap, I don’t know. But what I really know is that

I NEED ANSWERS!!
